title: Levellord and German verbs
content:
Okay, I know a lot of German words, that was the easy part.

I can put up with there being 5 words for 'the' and memorizing the genders of nouns.

I can understand the capitalization of all nouns and a sentence structure that is something like 'The German test I will pass not, because it too hard is.'

BUT:

LL: Morgen gehen ich zur Stadt!

Friend: Romflol! Sie sind lustig!

LL: Warum?

Friend: Gehe, Sie sagen gehe, aber Du gehst, er geht und sie gehen.

LL: WTF?

*later*

LL: Excuse me, can I have a book on verbs?

German teacher: Sure.

LL: Can I have another one? One in english?

GT: It is in english, go away.

*A passage from the book*

If a modal auxiliary is followed by an infinitive the past participle is the same as the infinitive; if there is no infinitive it takes the weak form.

LL: WTF????!

The past participle is the form that combines with the auxiliary verbs to form the compound past tense and the passive.

LL: [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-dead.gif[/img]

Please tell me that there's an easier way to do this than remembering every verbs past-present-future forms for Ich-Du-Sie-Konjunktiv.

A proud member of the signature stealing society

[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v410/Gannalev/Kazz.gif[/img]

"No one should be here."
-Levellord

title: Re: Levellord and German verbs
content:
I think the only real solution is to read and hear enough German that it becomes automatic. A lot of verbs are regular, so you only have to get the pattern once, which helps, and then remember the many exceptions. After a while you don't have to think about it, because saying, "Ich gehen" sounds as silly as saying "I is going". It's something you get over time. I've probably lost it by now, but I'll be taking German again next year. My advice is to read as much German as possible (out loud if it helps you) so that you can get the pattern ingrained.________________
[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v462/lemur821/YorpEye.png[/img]

title: Re: Levellord and German verbs
content:
Ah, don't worry. I got sent a rather full reply by someone I've never seen post. Apparently it is the german equivalent of the americian rappers B***h, usable as both an insult, derogatively, as a sexual inuendo or nickname. Interestingly I have also been introduced to the less cryptic insult Arsloch.

Harvey, try this begginning course in German:

English: Deutsch

Thats good. Das ist gut.

Oh darn. Fluch!

I would like to meet you. Gekommen hier.

Do you know where I may find a drink? Spiritus? Also Alkohol?

Where is the pub/bar? Wo is das bier haus?

Oh good, beer. wundervoll!i]

Germany is so much like home. [i]Alles ka[/i]

Thats a colourful shirt sir. Sind Sie ein homosexuell?

Can you help me have a good time? Sie haben Kokain?

Oh look, a policeman. Wir ist kaput!

title: Re: Levellord and German verbs
content:
With a little help from babel fish, I've proved that the German translations of English LL gave me was incorrect.

Englische Hollnder

That's good. Thats gut.

Oh darn. OH- Gestopftes.

I would like to meet you. Ich mchte Sie treffen.

Where is the pub/bar? Wo ist das pub/bar?

Germany is so much like home. Deutschland ist soviel wie Haus.

Thats a colourful shirt sir. Thats ein bunter Hemdsir.

Can you help me have a good time? Knnen Sie mir helfen, eine gute Zeit zu haben?

Yes, I know I deleted some.[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-rolleyes.gif[/img] If you use this site ([url=http://world.altavista.com/]world.altavista.com[/url]), you can see the entire site in different languages! (Too bad it doesn't include standard galactic.)-------------------

title: Re: Levellord and German verbs
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]Thats gut.[hr][/quote]
No, because Babelfish doesn't translate apostrophes. The correct form is "Das ist gut."

Also, those incorrect translations were a deliberate joke. Let's translate the German that LL gave you into English:

Gekommen hier - Come here
Spiritus/Alkohol - Spirits/Alcohol
wundervoll! - wonderful
Alles ka - Everything's (Don't know what "ka" is - probably means "crap")
Sind Sie ein homosexuell? - Are you homosexual?
Sie haben Kokain? - Do you have cocaine?
Wir ist kaput! - We are done for/screwed

Hohoho very satirical.[url=http://www.toxicsheep.com]www.toxicsheep.com[/url]
[img]http://www.toxicsheep.com/sigs/scrobblersig.php[/img]

[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

here are the correct translations:

English: Deutsch

Thats good: Das ist gut.

Oh darn: Mist!

I would like to meet you: Ich wrde dich/sie gern treffen.

Do you know where I may find a drink?: Wissen sie/weit du wo ich hier etwas zu trinken finde?

Where is the pub/bar?: Wo ist die Kneipe/Bar/Wirtshaus?

Oh good, beer: Oh gut, Bier!

Germany is so much like home: Deutschland ist zu Haus so hnlich.

Thats a colourful shirt sir. Das ist ein buntes Shirt.

Can you help me have a good time?: Knnen Sie/Kannst du mir helfen, eine schne Zeit zu haben?

Oh look, a policeman. Oh schau: ein Polizist!

title: Re: Levellord and German verbs
content:
Weltfrieden? Never heard of it.

Lets take a look at 'english':

Angst [Fear I believe]
Asprin [Means, well, asprin]
Autobahn [Realy fast road]
Blitz and Blitzkreig [Lightning and lightning war]
Cobalt [From old german Kobald, goblin]
Dachshund [The dog]
Diesel [Saying die as de, has to be german]
Delicatessen [Englishated Delikatessen, someplace to eat.]
Hinterland [Outback]
Kindergarten [Childs garden]
Kids [Corruption of Kind, child]
Noodle [Yes, really]
Poltergeist [Rumbling spirit.]
Rucksack [Backpack]
Schmooze [Corruption of Schmusen, a gentle kiss]
Scnitzel [Mmm, beef]
Wunderkind [Wonder kid, often used in academia]
Zeitgeist [The spirit of the time]

Dear lord, need I go on. Its no wonder english and german were considered the same language 1'500 years ago.A proud member of the signature stealing society

title: Re: Levellord and German verbs
content:
Using an indefinite article makes sense in English since homosexual can be a noun as well as an adjective, but the spelling of the noun form is slightly different in German (adds an "e"). So it's a little confusing.________________

title: Re: Levellord and German verbs
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]and how does one the difference between sie and Sie?[hr][/quote]
The verb forms after or preceding them? Sie takes an "en" ending, whereas sie takes a "t" ending.[url=http://www.toxicsheep.com]www.toxicsheep.com[/url]
[img]http://www.toxicsheep.com/sigs/scrobblersig.php[/img]

title: Re: Levellord and German verbs
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]LL trinken kein bier[hr][/quote]
Right: LL trinkt kein Bier.

The small "sie" means "she" ("Hamburger isst sie gerne."), the big "Sie" is the politeness form of "du" (you), for example if you speak with people who you don't know ("Wer sind Sie?") or with teachers ("Knnen Sie mir das erklren, Frau Schneider?").
- We want "The Universe is Toast" ! - [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-yorp.gif[/img]
